content: How can I help you today?

I'm not really sure where to start. My wife and I have been arguing a lot, mostly about how to handle our son's behavior. It's like everything is falling apart, and I don't even know if this counseling thing is going to help.

It sounds like things have been feeling really overwhelming for you, especially with the challenges of parenting and the strain on your relationship. It’s understandable to feel unsure about where to start or if this will help—it’s a lot to deal with. What’s been the most difficult part of all this for you?

Honestly, I feel stuck. Our son’s behavior is so out of control, and every time we try to address it, my wife and I end up arguing. I don’t even know what the right thing to do is anymore, and it’s taking a toll on everything—my marriage, my focus, even just feeling normal. I just want my family to feel okay again.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot, and it’s hard when you’re doing your best but feel unsure about how to move forward. It makes sense that you’d just want your family to feel okay again. It shows how much you care about your son and your wife. What do you think has been getting in the way of finding a way forward together?

I think a big part of it is that my wife and I have different ideas on how to handle our son's behavior, and instead of working together, we end up in these heated arguments. On top of that, I feel like I’ve lost the energy to even think straight about what to do—it’s just constant stress. It’s hard to even think about solutions when everything feels so heavy all the time.

It sounds like the constant stress and disagreements are really weighing you down, making it hard to see a clear direction forward. And when you’re feeling drained, it’s even tougher to figure out how to handle everything. Despite all of that, it’s clear that you really want to find a way to unite with your wife and support your son. What would it mean for you to feel like you and your wife are on the same page?

I think it would mean a lot. If we could work together instead of being at odds, maybe we could actually figure out how to help our son. I miss feeling like a team with her, but I don’t know how to get back to that when we’re both so frustrated and exhausted all the time.

Feeling like a team with your wife again seems like it would make a big difference for both your relationship and finding a path forward with your son. It’s tough to reconnect when exhaustion and frustration have built up, but the fact that you still want to work together says a lot. What do you think might be one small step toward starting to rebuild that connection with her?

Maybe we could just sit down and talk without arguing, but even that feels impossible some days. I don’t know—maybe finding a way to actually listen to each other without all the frustration getting in the way could help. I just don’t know how to make that happen.

It sounds like having a calm, understanding conversation with your wife feels like an important step, but also one that seems really challenging right now. Wanting to truly listen to each other suggests a strong desire to bridge this gap and work through the frustration. What do you think could make it feel just a little bit easier to approach that kind of conversation with her?

Maybe if we could set aside a specific time to talk, where we both agree to stay calm and focus on listening—like no blaming or bringing up past arguments—it might help. But honestly, I don't know if she’d go for it, or if I’ll even be able to keep my cool when I’m feeling this overwhelmed.

It sounds like setting aside time for a focused, calm conversation feels like it could be a helpful step, even though you’re unsure how it would go. You’re really trying to find a positive way forward, which shows how deeply you care about making things better. What do you think might help you feel more grounded and ready to approach the conversation, even with all the overwhelm you’re carrying?

I think maybe just taking a moment to myself before we talk could help—like a walk or just sitting quietly to clear my head. But honestly, I’ve been so stressed that even calming down feels hard. I just don’t know if I can hold it together when emotions are running so high.

Taking a moment for yourself, like a walk or some quiet time, sounds like it could give you the space to reset a bit before a tough conversation. It also sounds like the stress has been so persistent that even calming down feels like a real challenge. That’s such a heavy weight to carry. How have you been taking care of yourself, even with everything that’s been going on?

Honestly, I haven’t been taking care of myself much at all. I’m just so caught up in everything with my son and my marriage that I don’t feel like I have the time or energy to think about myself. It’s like I’m just running on empty, trying to keep everything from falling apart.

It sounds like you’ve been pouring so much of yourself into taking care of your family that there hasn’t been any space left for you. Running on empty like that can make everything feel even harder to manage. Taking care of yourself might feel like a lot to think about right now, but it could also help replenish some of the energy you’re using to hold everything together. What’s one small way you could start to give yourself even a little bit of that care?

Maybe I could try to take a few minutes each day, even just 10-15 minutes, to clear my head or do something small that I enjoy. It feels hard to justify focusing on myself when my family needs so much, but I guess I have to start somewhere.

It’s hard to prioritize yourself when your family needs so much, but recognizing the importance of even 10-15 minutes for yourself is a meaningful step. Making space for a small moment you enjoy could help you recharge, even just a little, to be there for them in the way you want to be. What’s something from the past—big or small—that you used to enjoy and might want to bring back into your day?

Maybe I could take a little time to play guitar again. I used to find it relaxing, but I haven't picked it up in months. It feels hard to think about doing something for myself, but maybe it could help.

Picking up your guitar again sounds like a meaningful way to reconnect with something that used to bring you relaxation. It could give you a small moment of peace, which might make it a little easier to handle everything else on your plate. What do you think could help you follow through on setting aside that time, even if it’s just a few minutes?
